text: People are disturbed not by things, but by the view which they take of them.
author: Epictetus

text: Man conquers the world by conquering himself.
author: Zeno Of Citium

text: We are more often frightened than hurt; and we suffer more in imagination than in reality.
author: Seneca

text: The impediment to action advances action. What stands in the way becomes the way.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: The greater the difficulty, the more glory in surmounting it. Skillful pilots gain their reputation from storms and tempests.
author: Epictetus

text: The soul becomes dyed with the colour of its thoughts.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: The unexamined life is not worth living.
author: Socrates

text: Strong minds discuss ideas, average minds discuss events, weak minds discuss people.
author: Socrates

text: The body should be treated more rigorously, that it may not be disobedient to the mind.
author: Seneca

text: Any person capable of angering you becomes your master.
author: Epictetus

text: Dwell on the beauty of life. Watch the stars, and see yourself running with them. Think constantly on the changes of the elements into each other, for such thoughts wash away the dust of earthly life.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: Never let the future disturb you. You will meet it, if you have to, with the same weapons of reason which today arm you against the present.
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: If you really want to escape the things that harass you, what you’re needing is not to be in a different place but to be a different person
author: Seneca

text: We have two ears and one mouth, so we should listen more than we say.
author: Zeno Of Citium

text: We are what we repeatedly do, therefore, excellence is not an act, but a habit.
author: Aristotle

text: Alexander the Great and his mule driver both died and the same thing happened to both .... They were absorbed alike into the life force of the world, or dissolved alike into atoms
author: Marcus Aurelius

text: Be kind, for everyone you meet is fighting a harder battle.
author: Plato

text: If you lay violent hands on me, you’ll have my body, but my mind will remain with Stilpo.
author: Zeno Of Citium

text: For we are mistaken when we look forward to death; the major portion of death has already passed. Whatever years be behind us are in death's hands.
author: Seneca

text: If one does not know to which port one is sailing, no wind is favorable
author: Seneca

text: Difficulties strengthen the mind, as labor does the body
author: Seneca

text: If you accomplish something good with hard work, the labor passes quickly, but the good endures; if you do something shameful in pursuit of pleasure, the pleasure passes quickly, but the shame endures.
author: Musonius Rufus

text: Knowing yourself is the beginning of all wisdom.
author: Aristotle

text: The greatest wealth is to live content with little.
author: Plato

text: When jarred, unavoidably, by circumstances, revert at once to yourself, and don’t lose the rhythm more than you can help. You’ll have a better grasp of the harmony if you keep on going back to it.
author: Marcus Aurelius
